dataset.title: Particle size fractionation of fungal and bacterial biomass in subalpine grassland and forest soils

abstract.para: Characterization of soil aggregates according to particle size fractions is a useful tool in process-oriented research into soil organic matter and biological properties. Substrate-induced respiration (SIR) inhibition was used to quantify microbial, fungal and bacterial biomass in particle size fractions of soils ranging from forest to grassland in a subalpine region of central Taiwan. In addition, ergosterol content was determined in the same samples to verify fungal biomass measured by SIR inhibition technique. Surface soil (0–10 cm) was fractionated into four particle size fractions: coarse sand (250–2000 Am), fine sand (53– 250 Am), silt (2–53 Am) and clay (0.2–2 Am). The larger sized fractions (N250 Am and 53–250 Am) contained higher levels of fungal ergosterol than the smaller sized ones (2–53 Am and 0.2–2 Am). The largest particle size fraction (250–2000 Am) from all studied habitats showed the highest level of microbial biomass, with no clear trend in microbial biomass level among the other size fractions. SIR-calculated fungal biomass level and ergosterol converted fungal biomass content were positively correlated (r=0.71, pb0.05), and such correlation decreased as biomass levels were high. Ratios of fungi to bacteria ranged between 0.6 and 1.3 in fractions obtained in this study. This study indicates a high variability of microbial (fungal and bacterial) biomass level among particle size fractions in soil, and that the large-sized fractions tend to contain a high level of microbial biomass in a given ecosystem.

section.title: Study site
section.para: Soils were collected at Tatajia, a subalpine area in the saddle of Jade Mountain (Yushan), central Taiwan (23828 N, 120854 E). The elevation is 2700 m and mean annual precipitation 4100 mm and temperature 9.5 C. The area was selected as a representative longterm ecological study site of subalpine forest ecosystems in Taiwan. The study area consists of metamorphosed sedimentary rock (Miocene Epoch) of sandstone and shale. The soils are Humic Dystrudepts with low base saturation. The coniferous forest is dominated by Chinese hemlock (Tsuga chinensis).
Less dominant species include Taiwan false cypress (Chamaecyparis formosensis), spruce (Picea morrisonicola)
and Armand’s pine (Pinus armandi). The grassland is dominated by dwarf bamboo (Yushania niitakayamensis) and alpine silver grass (Miscanthus transmorrisonensis).

section.title: Soil sampling
section.para: Surface soil (0–10 cm deep) was collected from the O/A horizon at three vegetation zones–grassland, transition zone and forest–in April 2000 (spring). Three composite samples were collected in each zone with use of a soil auger (8 cm diameter and 10 cm deep). A mixture of three sampling points formed a composite sample of a given zone. For soil samples with a shallow O/A horizon (b10 cm), the B layer soil was discarded, since microbial activities are concentrated in organic-rich layers. Visible material such as roots and litter were manually removed prior to
sieving the material through a 2-mm sieve. Soil was kept at 4 8C in the dark before use.

section.title: Physical fractionation of the soil
section.para: We used the procedure of Stemmer et al. (1998) to disperse the soil samples by low-energy sonication and separate the particle size fractions by a combination of wet sieving and continuous flow centrifugation. Fresh soil was dispersed in distilled water by use of a probe-type ultrasonic disaggregator (Misonix XL-2020) with 50 J sl output energy for 120 s (about 170 J g1 dry soil). Coarse sand (250–2000 Am) and fine sand (53–250 Am) were collected in sieves with a corresponding mesh size. The liquid passing through the sieves contained silt (2–53 Am) and clay (0.2–2 Am). The separation of the last 2 fractions and collection of silt (2–53 Am) were achieved by repeated
centrifugation at 190g. The supernatant was then centrifuged at 3800g to collect the clay fraction
g to collect the clay fraction (0.2–2 Am).

section.title: Ergosterol content
section.para: Fungal ergosterol content in soil and particles was determined according to the procedure of Ro¨ssner (1996), who modified the method of Zelles et al. (1987). About 2 g of fractionated moist soil sample was extracted and saponified with methanol (20 ml), ethanol (5 ml) and KOH (2 g) by heating at 708C for 30 min. After centrifugation, the supernatant was extracted with hexane (30 ml), then separated, and the upper hexane phase rotary was evaporated at 40 8C

until dry. The ergosterol was redissolved in 2 ml methanol and filtered through a 0.4-Am membrane filter. Samples (100 Al) were injected into a Spectra- Physics SP 8800 HPLC with a reverse-phase analytical column (Hypersil RPC-18, 5 Am, 1504.6 mm). The flow rate was set at 1.5 ml min1 and UV detector 282 nm. The mobile phase was 97%
methanol to 3% pure water. Fungal biomass content was calculated from ergosterol content by use of a conversion factor of 250 Ag1 biomass for 1 Ag1 ergosterol (Montgomery et al., 2000).

section.title: Substrate-induced respiration (SIR)
section.para: To determine microbial, fungal and bacterial biomass, substrate-induced total, fungal and bacterial respiration were measured according to the procedures of West (1986) and Henrot and Robertson (1994). Each soil particle size fraction was treated with no antibiotics (control), 32 mg ml1 streptomycin, 64 mg ml1 cycloheximide and 32 mg ml1 streptomycin combined with 64 mg ml1 cycloheximide. The inhibitor concentrations were selected on the basis

of the results of Imberger and Chiu (2001). Two replicates were prepared for each treatment. Samples were pre-incubated for 3 days at 25 8C. About 1.2 g of sample was weighed and put into 150-ml Erlenmeyer flasks. Two milliliters of solution of glucose (30 mg ml1) and antibiotics were added. The flasks were closed with double-sealed rubber stoppers and incubated at 25 8C. Headspace gas (1 ml) was sampled with use of a gas-tight syringe at the beginning and end of the incubation (5 h). Carbon dioxide concentration was estimated by use of a Hitachi 263-30 GC
with a 2 m2 mm Hayesep Q stainless steel column, thermal conductivity detector and integrator. Respiration rates and ratios of fungi to bacteria were calculated according to West (1986) as follows:

Eukaryote (fungal) respiration (B)=Total (noninhibited, control) respirationRespiration after addition of streptomycin. Prokaryote (bacterial) respiration (C)=Total (noninhibited, control) respirationRespiration after addition of cycloheximide.Ratio of fungi to bacteria=B/C.

The microbial biomass content was calculated by use of the conversion ratio of Anderson and Domsch (1978), whereby 1 ml CO2 h1 of total SIR (noninhibited, control) corresponds to 40 mg microbial biomass. Microbial biomass content was then partitioned into fungal and bacterial biomass content according to the fungi/bacteria ratio obtained from the above SIR rate (Anderson and Domsch, 1978).

section.title: Chemical analysis
section.para: Soil pH was determined in 1:2 soil to water. Cation
exchange capacity was measured with 1 M NH4OAc.
Organic C and total N content was measured with use
of a Fisons NA1500 elemental analyzer.

section.title: Statistical analysis
section.para: Data were converted by log transformation before applying ANOVA. Statistically significant differences ( pb0.05) between treatments were compared with the use of Duncan’s multiple range test (SAS, 2001). Regression analysis was used to determine correlations between SIR-calculated fungal biomass and ergosterol fungal biomass levels.
